conversations.content: Where It Began: Part One
The day it began, I stood alone. And yet, I was not lonely. For upon this hill, I would bear the fruit of a life writ large!
Ages passed, and life blossomed on the hill. Among them were two charming felines who loved to nap beneath my weighty boughs.
Then came the most auspicious event of all—my daughter's birth.
She was my darling. My beloved. I could gaze eternally upon her slumbering face; my love for her is as endless as the sea.
With the gift of my love, my daughter grew quickly, and soon formed an interest in the world beyond the hill.
＂I want to be like you, Mother!＂ she cried. ＂I want to create the world beyond the hill!＂
It was hard to believe such a large dream existed in one so small. Yet soon she decided to leave the hill, and because I loved her so, I did not stop her.
Many came to see her off, yet I paid them no mind. I could only watch her go and wonder if my own heart would collapse with sadness.
Would that I could have embraced her before she departed—but alas, I have only branches and leaves with which to encircle others.
And so, I sent my two feline friends to follow her. I bade them to make sure she was well, and to inform me if anything ever went amiss.
I heard nothing as the months and years went on, and constantly told myself such silence meant only that my daughter was alive and happy.
But then, a change came to the hill that I never expected...
Where It Began: Part Two
With thoughts of my daughter ever in my mind, I stood an endless vigil over the hill where it all began.  But then, the menace appeared.
It was a threat to my hill, yet was not calamity or fiend. Rather, it was the workings of the very life I had so carefully tended all those years.
The life I created had prospered into a civilization that stole mana from the very air and caused the earth to boil from heat.
Droughts became legion, and once- fertile fields went fallow. What irony, that the very life I had so carefully shepherded now threatened me!
Finally, I could go on no longer. My tough bark peeled and shattered. My boughs withered and broke. I knew I could no longer maintain my watch from my customary place.
I was sad, yet resigned—for I also knew an end eventually came for all.
But as I finally began to let go, a most unexpected thing occurred...
I heard a sound—a sound of life. Yet not a single blade of grass still stood upon my hill. So what, then, had made the noise?
I lifted my heavy lids and saw my beloved daughter standing before me as a woman grown, my two cats at her side as familiars.
＂I'm home, Mother,＂ she said with a wave of her staff, as if imploring me to look around.
My weary eyes suddenly burst open, for my once-empty hill was now fully alive with the power of creation.
My roots suddenly found new water. My leaves burst forth with green life. Renewed, I lowered a single branch down to my daughter's angelic  face and said:
＂Welcome home, Freyja.＂
Thus was all the nature of Alberia born from one great tree, and thus will a beloved daughter continue to preserve the land with a power that exceeds even her mother's!
